item.description:
Currency Sakana is a linen bag of metal coins, that allows for a variety of games with mechanics such as bidding, dexterity, and variable player powers.

In the first game "It's in the Bag", players will all start with a set number of yen bills and coins equaling 7,500 yen. Players will always add one currency item to the bag (it is never allowed to make change), and then hold a blind bid for the contents. All bids are then placed to the side to be added to the bag for the next bidding round, and the highest bidder takes all of the current yen in the bag. Play continues like this, with players bidding on the last rounds bids plus one new currency item from each player, until one player has 10,000 yen or more and is declared the winner!

—description from the publisher

Conflict of Alliances: Three Kingdomsï¼ˆé­æ­¦ä¸‰å›½ï¼‰is a 2 or 4 player (does not support 3) game about diplomacy and warfare in the period of the Three Kingdoms in ancient China.

This game integrates diplomacy, warfare, reinforcements and initiative in a simple card driven mechanic. Each player plays actions by the cards in their hand and tries to control more areas by the end of game.

The game has different winning goals for each scenario.

name.value: Flaming Continent: Record of the Three Kingdoms Ver. Lord
燃烧的大陆 枭雄篇

item.description:
Flaming Continent: Record of the Three Kingdoms Ver. Lord is a board game that allows you play as a lord in Three Kingdoms. The game also support AI batter for 0 player.

There are 4 seasons in a round. In each round, player should bid different actions and active them. Players are trying to control the most areas to win the game.

Hidden Paths is an abstract/puzzle game that involves two lost explorers wandering a grand and wondrous forest. In their travels, they uncover and score paths that lead them closer to the exit. When the exit is revealed, the first player to score onto or move onto the Exit tile with the most points wins the game!

In Hidden Paths, players will be viewing the Clearing tile on which their player pawn are on and determining if they are able to create the route from it within the Forest to score victory points. To score a route, players look to see if their pawn and clearing tile are on a starting route marker denoted by a gold marker on the clearing tile. Players will then visualize the route on the clearing tile with the tiles in the forest. If the route fits within the forest grid, the player may spend an Action card to ‘score’ this route. They will then travel their pawn to another gold route marker listed on the route of the clearing tile. If the clearing tile they move or score onto has not be revealed, they will reveal it immediately. The player will then score victory points based upon the victory point notated on the clearing tile and/or matching both colors and symbols on their scoring Action card.

—description from the designer

item.description:
In the Inuit language, "tukilik" is used to define an object that carries a message, and the northern landscapes are densely populated with such objects. The most well known of these are the inukshuk, that is, structures of rough stones traditionally used by Inuit people as a landmark or commemorative sign, with the stones often being stacked in the form of a human figure.

During each turn in Tuki, you attempt to construct an inukshuk based on the die face rolled using your stones and blocks of snow. Players have only a limited number of pieces with which to construct the inukshuk, so you'll need to be creative and use the three-dimensional pieces in multiple ways, such as to counterbalance other pieces or even build on top of existing pieces. A solution always exists — you just need to discover it!

You can choose from two levels of difficulty when playing Tuki to level the playing ground between newcomers and experts. Be swift, yet precise, and transform your stones into messengers of the north...

item.description:
A new one of micro-game series made by Jog Kung.

In this game, each player tries to dye the clothes in his/her indigo plant, first from white cloth to blue cloth, then to patterned cloth. The one who successfully dyed 8 patterned clothes first wins the game!

Players take turn to do one of the following:
1. Take a card from the supply and place it on his/her plant.
2. Take a card from the supply and add it to his/her hand.
3. Place a card from his/her hand to his/her plant.

The game ends when one of the following happens:
1. One of the player has dyed 8 or more patterned clothes.
2. There is only 1 card in any of the supply rows.

name.value: Sherlock Holmes Detektyw doradczy: Nie ma zysku bez ryzyka
Sherlock Holmes: Detektyw doradczy – Nie ma zysku bez ryzyka

item.description:
Inspector Gregson came to Baker Street for help from Sherlock with a case of a girl that dies in hospital yesterday. She was beaten to death.

Sherlock Holmes: Detektyw doradczy - Nie ma zysku bez ryzyka (Sherlock Holmes: Consulting Detective - Nothing ventured, nothing gained) is a free print and play scenario for Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective!

This is a standalone game. It comes with an excerpt from the address book, map, and newspaper, and does not need any items from the base game.

name.value: Clumsy Thief in the Candy Shop

item.description:
From the creators of the original, award-winning Clumsy Thief game, this hilarious version has players snatching candy stacks that add to 20. All candy is up for grabs in this fast-paced card game. Strategy, addition skills, luck and a great sense of humor are required.

HOW TO PLAY: Players make candy stacks from their dealt cards. Take a players' stack if you have a card that makes 20 when added to the top card of their stack. But that's just the beginning! Thief cards steal candy cards. Jail cards stop thief cards. In the end, the player with the most candy cards wins.

—description from the publisher

Ab durch die Mauer is the family game about ghosts who won't be stopped by mere walls when they hunt for the best costumes throughout a rotating, magnetic castle.

Each player has their own ghost inside the castle. When it is a player's turn, that player can perform up to three magical movements. Not only can they move their ghost from space to space, but they can also move sliders underneath the floor or even rotate the whole playing board. Thanks to the magnets inside the sliders, the ghosts will fly through the castle's walls while hunting for the best possible costume. The first player to collect four different costume pieces wins.

item.description:
Ganjifa playing cards were introduced and popularized by Mughal emperors in the 16th century. It has always been one of the popular card games among Moghul Emperors, Emirs and Maharajas. When it was first established, the cards started spreading to many regions of India in the original form or Hindu form. Nowadays it’s difficult to find a suitable deck to play in India. Only a small handful of artisans located in 2 cities still produce Ganjifa cards.

This is where we come in. Let me introduce you to Ganjifa Play.

In Ganjifa Play, players take turns playing suits, taking tricks, and building temples. Ganjifa Play is a trick-taking, hand management game for 2-4 players. Several chips are randomly drawn from the bag to determine (one round, one square, and one diamond) the highest suite symbol that round, the time of day, and the location.

The Round pawn sets the highest deck in the game for that round. The Raja of this suit goes first.

The Diamond pawn, with the time of day symbol indicates the suit that defines the direction of the game. For example, the player whose Raja matches the chosen time of day makes the toughest decision. Does gameplay go Clockwise or Counterclockwise?

The Square pawn defines the location. The players who Raja matches may exchange two cards of their choice with any two from an opponent’s hand.

Once all cards have been played, players count their tricks to determine the winner that round. The winner places the base of their temple onto the mandala playing field. If a number of players have the same number of tricks, all players are deemed winners that round and should put the first part of their temple on the playing field.

The goal is to be the first player to build a complete temple made up of three parts.

—description from the designer

The object of this game is for the PLAYERS, using dice and playing pieces, to travel on the gameboard from a RESIDENCE SQUARE to the shopping locations shown on their SHOPPING LISTS. The first PLAYER to return to his RESIDENCE with TRAVEL CARDS for all locations on his SHOPPING LIST wins the game!
—description from the rulebook

The gameboard, which comes in six puzzle-like pieces, depicts a highly simplified map of Cleveland, Ohio, with featured local landmarks. The instructions pamphlet has contact information for Cleveland attractions printed in the margins. In addition to the game components, real-world coupons are also included for Cleveland businesses that were around when the game was made in 1980.
—user summary

"Only a few steps and those sweetly delicious berries you craved so much are yours to eat. They're right there, just take them! But you hesitate, as things may not be as they seem. That vague shadow you spotted earlier could be anything... and anywhere. It could be one of your forest friends, looking for food, as usual. But maybe it's something more dangerous, watching your every move, planning its time to strike..."

In Oh, Fox!, players secretly take on the roles of animals of the forest, each with their own unique ability. Prey animals are gathering food while being hunted by the predator. Across 7 turns, players move across the board by simultaneously playing 1 face-up movement card each turn. However, their figurines don't actually move until the end of the game! Until then, players try to hide their own identity while attempting to figure out who the others are, before it is too late...

—description from the designer

Deliver your customers to stations situated all across town, and be the first to get them to each before your competition in this latest title from famed game designer, Reiner Knizia.

In Stations, players will compete to be the first to visit seven stations, represented by colored discs on both the board and in front of them. The first player to get rid of all their discs wins. On the way, they collect tickets to help them maneuver around the board, hop off one transport and make their way to the next transport that will take them where they need to go. But watch out! If you're waiting at the station hoping to hop on the next "shuttle", the transport might just pass you by!

Stations is part of the Age Fluid series of games with gameplay that is, at once, perfect for entire families and can be built up to appeal to the more serious gamer. The game comes with the base rules and variants designed to make the strategy ramp up.

Dodoresque: Cherry Blossom is a funny card game for 2-4 players. Each Player takes the role of a Dodo, trying to build the best nest possible.

To do so, the Dodos can go on Adventures, Trade and Build.

Each player starts out with the drawing of 3 starting cards, of which one is discarded to create the exchange stack.

To gather nest building materials, the Dodo Players have to go on Adventures in one of three card stacks (drawing cards). Those stacks consist of 2 different card types: Material and Action. To get better material cards, you need the right action cards on your hand to counter certain effects and be able to take the materials on your hand. Material cards from your hand can be built into a nest by playing them on the table in front of you. A nest consists of a maximum of 6 cards. Goal of the game is to score as many points as possible with different combinations of cards in your nest.

Another option to get the cards you need is to trade with other players, but not in a direct way. Depending on the number of players there are some cards available as an exchange stack. Players can trade cards from their hand with the exchange stack.

Each material card has one of three types, one of four themes and an individual value between 1 and 3. To build the perfect nest you require 2 cards of each type, preferably of the same theme and with an individual value as high as possible.

The game ends when one of the adventure card stacks is used up or one of the Dodo characters has lost all of its hit points.

Dodoresque consists of 90 cards, over 60 of them with unique artworks of our Dodos and their adventures.

While the mechanics of Cherry Blossom are the same as in the first Dodoresque, the game has all new illustrations, characters, landscapes, and some new special action cards.

Dodoresque: Cherry Blossom can be combined with Dodoresque: Jungle Fever for a game with up to 8 players.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Trinity is an abstract two player strategy game where you can exercise your tactical expertise and pattern recognition skills to capture your opponent. The game is designed to be compact, yet engaging for ease-of-travel and making more use of downtime during your adventures.

Players have 5 tokens each and can either place a token, move a token, or place a dead space on the board. You capture your opponent's token by maneuvering your own to restrict their movement. The opponent then receives a dead space token to potentially turn the tides. A player wins when 3 of the opponent's tokens are captured.

-description from designer

Game play in Heul doch! Mau Mau is simple, but it may bring you to tears all the same when you give points away to other players.

The game consists of 98 cards, with 1-7 each appearing twice in seven colors. Each player starts with a random card face up in front of them as a personal discard pile as well as a hand of four cards. On a turn, you must play one card from your hand following the familiar game play rules of matching the color or number. Ideally you want to play on your own pile, but if the card you would play matches the top card of your left- or right-hand neighbor's discard pile, then you must play it there instead!

Maybe you can choose a card in hand that matches only your top card? If you have no valid play or don't want to give points away to someone else, you can play the card face down on your stack, showing the weepy onion on the card back. On your next turn, you can play any card you like on your pile — except if it matches a neighbor's top card, of course, in which case you must give it away. (You can't play on a neighbor's onion card.)

Once all the cards have been played, everyone scores for the cards in their pile — but first they must count the number of onion cards in their pile. However many onions they have, they must remove all matching number cards prior to scoring. If you have four onions, for example, you must discard all 4s — and this is bad since all cards score points equal to their value. If you have ten onions, then you first discard all 7s, then all 3s. Whoever has the most points wins!

Heul doch! Mau Mau includes twelve special action cards that can be used to twist up game play when played instead of a number card:


 Catapult: All players with the highest number on their pile discard those cards to the center of the table.
 Beach towel: Exchange your top card (whether onion or number) with the top card of another player's pile.
 Merry-go-round: Decide whether all players pass their topmost card to the player on their left or right.
 Werewolf: All players must flip their top card from number to onion or vice versa.

item.description: In Red Peak, the players are daring adventurers who have discovered a new volcanic island — but then "Red Peak" on the north of the island decides to live up to its name and starts rumbling. An eruption seems imminent! Salvation is possibly only by returning to the beach as quickly as possible where — fingers crossed — a boat awaits the group. Players will be fighting using every means possible to make their way through the jungle, with the lava ready to spill onto their necks at any moment. Will the group reach the boat in time before lava engulfs their camp on the beach?

Panzer Strike: Western Front is not a historical wargame but an engaging dynamic simulation of tank combat.

This is a first game in the series of Panzer Strike games which is centered around a theme of tank battles on the Western Front. This is not a depiction of any particular battle, but a simulation of possible tactical conflicts between the Allied and German forces during the 1944-45 period, in an urban environment.

Dice are a part of this game but strategy and positioning can always mitigate unlucky rolls. Still, even the most heavily armoured tank on the battlefield can be incapacitated by a lucky shot, but you should never rely on it. The outcome of each encounter depends predominantly on the tactical decisions taken.

The movement of the piece consists of a series of individual steps (forward movements to the adjacent square or a rotation in place by 45°) which resembles the movement of tracked vehicles in real life. In the Simplified rules, the destruction upon the action of shooting depends on the Firepower of the shooting tank (determined by red dice rolls), Armour value of the target vehicle (different values for each side of every tank type) and the Distance between the tanks (determined by a special ruler): the tank is destroyed if the Firepower is greater than the sum of the Armour and Distance values. In the Core Rules, the movement of the pieces is identical, but the difference is that in addition to Firepower, Armour, and Distance factors, there is a fourth one: Accuracy. Its introduction, along with some other elements, makes the game even more dynamic and realistic.

—description from the publisher

Moonrakers is a game of shipbuilding, negotiation, and the occasional backstabbing set in a pirate-filled space-faring future. The players form a loose band of Pirates called the Moonrakers, but while they are united in name, actual alliances are shaky as players are pitted against each other in the quest to become the most infamous pirate in the galaxy.

Moonrakers is a co-op/competitive deck builder in which players choose contracts to attempt alone or with allies in order to gain prestige and wealth. After negotiating terms with allies, players use their decks and hand of 5 cards to play Thrusters, Shields, Weapons, Reactors, and Crew to fulfill the requirements on each contract. Each type of card has other effects to keep your turn moving such as extra actions, drawing additional cards, and protecting you from damage suffered while attempting the contract, so play order is important.

Players gain powerful decks and special abilities by upgrading their ships and hiring crewmembers with the money they receive from contracts. This helps them accomplish more difficult and rewarding contracts alone, which lets them keep more prestige for themselves.

Who receives the prestige, money, and risk of damage from contracts is all negotiable, but if you don't make your offers enticing enough, players may be tempted to betray you! The first player to 10 Prestige wins, but be careful as taking damage on contracts reduces your prestige!

-description from designer
Kuhle Kühe (a.k.a. Cool Cows) is a card game, not a herd of cows. Do not milk it.

item.description:
Conflict: Song and Jin is a game simulate the war between Song Dynasty and Jin Dynasty in China. The game has 8 turns, begins 1126 and end in 1142.
It has the similar system with Twilight Struggle. It's a card-driven area control simulation game. How to use the event cards and play as the correct action is the key point of the game.

Have you seen this gnome? Gnomes are a mischievous lot. They love playing tricks on people by hiding misplaced objects. And the only way to get back your belongings is to catch the culprit. Too bad the gnomes are so sneaky! The clever rotating device only allows you to see the card with the gnome for a split second: this should be enough to compile a portrait of the troublemaker. What did the beard look like? And what about the shoes? And the hat? Identify the most elements in order to win the card — and the points!

This cold war space board game was produced in Estonia when under control of the USSR. 
This simple roll and move game has players race from earth to the moon. The path has players leaving earth and entering the moon in orbital trajectories. Landing on some numbered spaces will advance players while other spots sends a player backwards. To land on the moon a player enters a tight circular orbit needing the correct number to land. 
The winner is the player to first land on the moon.

—user summary

In the early 19th century, the western world trembled with fear and excitement around new medical advances. The medical horror, Frankenstein, was a bestselling novel and medical shows, in which physicians would electrify corpses, pull teeth, or peddle their “miracle cures”, drew huge crowds.

In Trepanation, players take the role of fraudulent doctors in this era, performing medical shows for the gullible public, and vying to become the most famous medical performer.

The game takes place over six days (rounds). At the start of each day, players prepare their schedules by booking time-slots at locations around town. Then the day’s events happen according to these schedules: players gather medicine and equipment, employ accomplices, bribe the police, and perform shows. But not all plans run smooth. Other players will create stock shortages, steal your audience, and snatch up those essential time-slots! Performing shows in related sets grant fame bonuses, as does getting your name in the local newspapers. Grave-robbing in the night damages your reputation, but earns cash! At the end of a busy week, the player who has earned the most fame wins the game.

There are lots of action spaces in this worker placement game because the emphasis is on timing your actions correctly to make the most of your limited resources.

—description from the publisher

In this children's game from the Winnie the Pooh universe, up to 4 players try to fill their honey pots with honey. To do this each player rolls the die in turn and moves the Winnie playing piece across the field. Depending on the symbol, even to which one lands, certain "tasks" must be fulfilled. The goal is to collect 5 honey tokens of one color and fill it into its honey pot. The hunny tokens (in 4 different colors) lie hidden in the middle of the playing field. If you are allowed to turn an hunny token (one of the "tasks") and if it has the right color, you may keep it. Otherwise you have to put it back on the playing field. The other players should remember the location of the hunny token (if it has the appropriate color for them) to collect it later (if allowed).

—user summary

As an apprentice Ninja, it’s time for you to show all your skills in challenging and exciting tricky trials. Will you be quicker, stronger, smarter…. or simply more concentrated than your opponents? Your training alternates collective trials and duels, in a series of varied tests drawn randomly. But whether you are challenging the whole group and head-to-head with another ninja, there will be only one rule: be the best at your trial! For example, try to be the first player to place a Ninja meeple on each of your fingertips! Try to guess how many ninjas your opponent put in the box just by shaking it! Be the quickest to assemble 5 wood logs vertically! Be strong enough to collect points depending on your score, but be also strategic enough when you bet on the winner of each duel! Ninja Academy is a hilarious, fast-paced and highly replayable new dexterity game!

—description from the publisher

Impression is about the history of printing. You manage your own manufacture to be the most successful in the book printing business. Involves development from Gutenberg to the present.

In your turn you choose to:

 Place a tile from the common supply to the typesetter. Now you rotate a rondel according to the number of tiles within the row and column, and the color of the used tile.
 Buy a tile from the typesetter. You pay as many coins as the number of the missing tiles in the chosen row and column.
 Get coins from the rondels.




Then you can do an order fulfillment phase. You can get new orders, also you can pay resources to make progress with your actual orders.

During your game you develop your own manufacture, get new abilities, collect tiles and fulfill orders. At the end of the game, who has the most victory points, wins.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Winner of the "Invent a game, become GRANNA’s author" contest.
Managing a nature reserve for fantastic monsters is a real challenge.
Check yourself in the role of managers of newly emerging monster parks. Try to buy cards of whimsical creatures - floating in the sky, walking on the ground or living underwater. Only wise budget management will make tourists from around the world to queue exclusively to your Monster Parks.

—user summary

name.value: Horse Club: Über Stock und Stein

item.description:
Oh dear! The little foal Cookie has left the paddock alone. Curious, it has explored its surroundings and quite far away from the Lakeside court. You are the Horse Club friends Sofia, Hannah, Lisa and Sarah. Together, you're helping Cookie to find the way back to the horse farm. Hurry up so the foal reaches his stable before dark!

To guide Cookie home safely, you roll the symbols shown on the individual boxes of the board. If you roll the moon, a strip of the board is turned on the night side. If Cookie reaches its stable before it is dark (before all the stripes are upside down on the table) you have won the game together.

A Gorinto is a type of Japanese pagoda of the five elements: earth (cube), water (sphere), fire (pyramid), air (crescent), and void (lotus). It often housed the relic of a Buddha or saint, and together represented the realm of perfect understanding.

In Gorinto, players take turns selecting element tiles from the Path (perimeter) and moving them onto the Mountain (game board). Each element collects in a specific pattern. The elements collected each turn will allow you to collect more elements over the turns and rounds.

Points are scored at the end of each round based on goals selected at the start of the game, as well as the elements chosen (that may change from round to round). The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

Will you be the player who achieves perfect understanding?

—description from the publisher

Cores da Guerra is a deckbuilding game set in ancient times period, more specifically in the Hellenistic period.

You are a general trying to achieve 7 victory points playing with Rome, Macedonia, Celts and Carthage and unify the Mediterranean sea in a great empire. These points can be achieved by military (pitched battles), political points (owning all the faction colors in your camp) and economical points (having three or more cards from the same faction in your camp). There is assault and raids against the adversary camp to slow down their economical engine.

The game is heavily based in wargame concepts in a very light way, but historically accurate. You will see light and heavy troops, infantry, cavalry, missile troops, terrain bonuses, etc. Cores da Guerra is divided in Campaigns. Each campaign is subdivided into three phases: A preparation phase in which players buy cards in the Market, set down cards in the area called camp, use abilities, assault or raid adversary camp, etc. When all players pass in their turn, the combat phase begins. Finally there is the renovation phase.

—description from the designer

Ohanami consists of a deck of 120 cards that are numbered from 1-120, with each card having one of four symbols on it. The game lasts three rounds, with players scoring at the end of each round, in addition to bonus scoring at the end of the game.

At the start of a round, each player receives a hand of ten cards. Each player chooses two cards, then passes the remaining cards to the left. All players reveal their cards at the same time, then decide whether to use 0, 1, or 2 of them in personal rows of cards. When you start a row, you can use any card; to add a card to an existing row, that card must be higher than the row's highest card or lower than the lowest one. A player can have at most three rows of cards. Discard any cards you don't use.

Players repeat this drafting, passing, and playing process until they have played ten cards. The first round ends, and players now receive 3 points for each blue card in their rows.

Players then receive a new hand of ten cards to start round 2, once again choosing two cards and passing the rest, but now to the right. Players continue building on the rows that they already have, scoring 3 points for each blue card and 4 points for each green card at the end of round two.

For round three, players have ten more cards and pass cards to the left once again. At the end of this round, players once again score for their blue and green cards, while also receiving 7 points for each gray card in their rows. Additionally, each player scores for their pink cherry blossom cards, with these cards having a pyramidal scoring structure: one card = 1 point, two cards = 3, three cards = 6, etc. Whoever has the highest total score wins!

item.description:
Thirty years ago, a large meteor crashed into a field outside Hagerstown Maryland, bringing the whole world to a standstill and halting the Civil War in its tracks. The United States had banded together, setting aside their differences, simply to survive the aftermath of this catastrophic event.

It was soon discovered that the meteor was a curious metallic alloy, referred to as “Element X”, which had an unexpected characteristic. It caused water to burst into steam

The Heist is a strategic game of deduction and luck. Your goal is to steal pieces of the worlds most valuable resource known as 'Element X'. A seventeen card deck contains many characters eager to get their hands on Element X. On a turn, you draw one card, and play one card using that characters action, trying to deduce who's who and eliminate them from the game and be the first to steal 7 pieces of Element X.

—description from the designer

item.description:
Do you want to try your hand in corruption?
We're a corrupt business firm and today we're going to make a killing without the middleman! After finding a bargain, let's make a deal. But being friendly is just for appearances! You'll have to outwit everyone even your superiors! Corruption is deception. Do you have what it takes?

As vicious intermediary companies, choose to rake off the current project fees within the "budget" together via blind bids or "prepare" for upcoming projects by drawing cards. If the amount bid exceeds the "budget", the greediest player must discard their profits. If all of the bids remain under "budget", everyone scores their bid. Keep playing until the deck runs out.

PENNY DREADFUN: a role-playing, comedy board game set in Victorian London, full of occultism, historical and literary characters, and an absurd sense of humour. A game for everyone that may be played and replayed over and over again thanks to its huge amount of cards - and all the possible player interactions that it offers!

Each player takes on the role of one of ten unusual characters who begin their search for Queen Victoria. Each driven by their own motives, they will have to navigate the streets of industrial revolution London, explore mysterious tombs and underground canals, and finally - make their way through the nine circles of Hell itself! During their journey they will face many foes, collect amazing loot, befriend powerful companions, and, of course - fight each other.

The hero that brings Queen Victoria to the Buckingam Palace will be the ultimate winner. It may be the strongest player, it may be the smartest one; it might be the one who found the Queen, but it also might be the one who nicked her at the end of the road. Well, whoever it may be - the winner can be only one!

item.description:
Chakkan is a card game based on the fantastic world of Chakkan. It is a 2 player game where memory, strategy and a bit of luck will make you the champion of your universe.
The game is to get skills by turning and discovering letters, you can identify them with their color and number, but do not trust your memory can be treacherous just like your rival. After you've got enough cards you can display different abilities to attack, provoke or defend your opponent or finally use your character's unique ability.
—description from the designer

Chakkan , es un juego de cartas basado en el mundo fantástico de Chakkan, es un juego de 2 jugadores donde la memoria, la estrategia y un poco de suerte te harán el campeón de su universo. 
El juego consiste en ir consiguiendo habilidades al ir volteando y descubriendo cartas, estas las puedes identificar con su color y número, pero no te confíes la memoria puede ser traicionera al igual que tu rival. Después de que has conseguido suficientes cartas puedes desplegar diferentes habilidades para atacar, provocar o defenderte de tu contrincante o por último utilizar la habilidad única de tu personaje.
—description from the designer (Spanish)

Maybe It's Poison is a game for 3-8 players where several guests sit down for tea, but only a few leave alive. Cups are shuffled and placed facedown on the table in front of each player with one extra cup than there are players. Players take turns to check the cups, memorize them to discover their delicious tea, and use action cards to rotate the cups' positions. The person with the tea in front of them when 'Cheers!' is said wins! The rest are poisoned...

—description from the publisher

Fickle is an inverse set collection card game for three to five players. Fickle features the legendary fairy art of Amy Brown, and is designed by Glenn Cotter.

Your goal is to build the strongest Fairy Alliance in 5 rounds and win the Queen’s Crown. You do this by keeping Fairies in your Alliance that gain you Favor points. Each card represents a single Fairy from one of the five Families. Each Family has a unique Power that enables you to improve your Alliance and thwart your opponents. Every round you will be choosing a single Fairy, playing it into your Alliance tableau, then resolving the Family Power. At the end of 5 rounds, the player with the highest total Favor score in their Alliance is the winner.

Easy... except with all those Powers, Fairies don’t seem to stay in one Alliance for long.

They tend to be... Fickle.

How to play:

Players compete for the most Favor points by making their own Alliance of fairies. Throughout the game players trick their opponents by passing them Fairy cards using "press your luck" card stacking rules. When a Fairy is added to an Alliance it must activate its Fairy Power. At the end of the game, players score Favor based on the composition of their Alliances.

Set Up
Fickle is a "Shuffle Builder" game. Players decide which 5 Fairy suits to play during the game. Every Fairy suit has its own unique power and gorgeous art. With 15+ Fairy suits to choose from, customization and replay value is very high.

Game Play
Fickle is played in 5 rounds. The winner has the most Favor (card points) at the end of game.

Each round players are dealt 3 cards. All players decide the order of the three cards, stack the cards, then pass the stack in that round’s direction. Thus, players will receive a 'press your luck' deck, created by their neighbor each round.

Players must "Pick or Pass" -- choose the top card of the stack or discard it to see the next card. Once the press your luck draw is completed, each player has one fairy card in hand.

Players now take turns, adding their chosen Fairy to their Alliance (tableau) and resolve the Fairy Power on their card. Highest Favor (card point value) goes first. These powers create fun effects that impact scoring, discard cards, exchange cards and more.

Once all Fairy Powers are resolved, start the next round.

Scoring
After the 5th round, players score their Alliances. Each suit of Fairy cards in an Alliance is scored separately. Because Fairies want equal influence in an Alliance, scores are based on an inverse scoring curve:


 1 card of a suit: Score its Favor value (ex. a Favor 3 card is worth 3 points)
 2 cards of a suit: Score ZERO (ex. a Favor 3 card and Favor 2 card is worth 0 points)
 3-4 cards of a suit: Score the NEGATIVE value of the highest card (ex. a Favor 3 card, a Favor 2 card, and a Favor 1 card is worth -3 points)
 5 or more cards of a suit “Shoot the Moon": Score the summed value of all cards (ex. a Favor 3 card, Favor 2 card, Favor 1 card, Favor 2 card, and Favor 4 card is worth 12 points)


The player with the highest Favor score wins.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A race through a Mayan temple.

The movements are set on a 4x4 matrix, searching for the right symbols to move.
Sleight of hand and eys are required in this run!

On the base of fifteen puzzle, each player must find the right symbol displayed on dice. Some cell cover the board, some cell is transparent, so won't be easy cover all the symbols.

The first player who arrives at the center of the mayan temple, wins the game!

—description from the publisher

Falling Koalas is a card game all about koalas. Drop Bears, as they are affectionately called, are known to eat eucalyptus leaves and sleep all day. Although seemingly cute and cuddly, they attack!

The game involves intense strategy and a bit of luck where players battle to see who will be the last koala hanging. It's easy to learn and takes 10-20 minutes to play.

The game is simple. Be the last koala alive and win the game
Play cards from your hand and end your turn by drawing a card. If you draw a falling koala card, you fall and are out of the game unless you can save yourself. Strategically play your cards to put yourself in the best position to win or force other players to fall.

Game play:

 View your hand, keeping your cards hidden from all other players.
 Play a card by placing it face up on the table.
 End your turn by drawing a card from the draw pile.
 If you draw a falling koala card, you're out unless you have a catch or sleep card.
 If you have a catch or sleep card, you're safe. Place it on top of the falling koala card in the discard pile. This ends your turn.
 Use your cards to attack your friends and put yourself in the best position to win.




—description from the designer

Can you keep a secret?
There’s someone who’s very special to me.

In this game, one card represents a very special role: Senpai. Everybody is trying to get Senpai’s attention, but it’s not that easy! First, they have to build up their charms and work up the confidence to make a confession. Trade cards and build the cutest character you can, and be the first to admit your feelings to Senpai… if you know who has the card!

Senpai Notice Me! is a sweet, lighthearted game of homoromantic silliness, matching colours and deducing hidden information. (It’s also very pink!)

—description from the publisher

The game of the BBC TV show of the same name. Licensed by BBC Worldwide.

Description from the box " Prove you're an Expert in this Game of Valuations, Bluff and Antique Trivia. "

A simple roll and move mechanic and set collection enlivened by the opportunity to estimate values and learn from expert guidance included in the cards. Very much suited to fans of the long-running U.K. TV show.

—user summary

Four dogs have buried their prized treasures in the yard — but they can’t remember where! In Dig Dog Dig, players take turns digging up the yard racing to be the first doggie to find all five of their favorite toys! Dig Dog Dig features fast and fun gameplay with a “backyard-in-a-box” that will make the whole family come play in the yard again and again!

Players begin by hiding each other's toys in the yard. On a player's turn they move their dog to a new location and look inside the hole. They keep any of their on toys they find and then re-hide all others. The player to find all five of their toys wins the game.

-description from designer

item.description:
In the year 2299, decimated by a devastating global nuclear war, humanity abandoned Old Earth with great haste, seeking refuge in the Alpha Centauri star system. After a long and arduous journey, the human remnants settled on an Earth-like planet orbiting the star Proxima Centauri. Having barely escaped extinction, humankind united with one purpose to build their new home.

Over the centuries that followed, as the human race recovered and regained its strength, the struggle for power also intensified. Soon, humanity separated into six factions, each colonizing their own home world and fighting for dominance and control over the other factions. Seemingly having forgotten the calamity of times past, a full-scale war broke out between the factions. Once again, the human race was suffering destruction at the hands of one another.

In the midst of the raging conflict, whispers and rumours of an unknown threat began to surface, an approaching darkness from the outer reaches of the star system. Just three days ago, our greatest fear was confirmed — we are not alone! A powerful alien race of Centaurian origin has emerged, determined to eradicate the human disease from their home star system.

The fate of humankind hangs in the balance! Will we finally manage to put our blood-stained past behind us and unite to face our new common enemy? Or is the urge to rule and conquer too great to spare us from doom? Before long, these questions will all be answered ... whether we want it or not!

In Exodus Chronicles you take on the role of one of six human factions, fighting for survival and dominance in an empire-building saga of epic proportions! Choose the primary path of your faction and elect the leader you believe is most capable of guiding your faction towards victory. Along the way, you must make clever decisions at every turn as you explore the sectors surrounding your home planet, expand the reach of your budding empire, exploit newly discovered worlds for their resources, and exterminate enemies that stand in your way.

Exodus Chronicles is a modern reimplementation and streamlined redesign of critically acclaimed Exodus: Proxima Centauri and its two expansions Edge of Extinction and Event Horizon. The game features six asymmetrical factions, each offering multiple choices of starting home worlds and faction leaders.

While the loved and praised game experience remains true to its predecessor, Exodus Chronicles is not merely a reprint of Exodus: Proxima Centauri. Each game mechanism has been thoroughly revisited and redesigned with the purpose of improving, enhancing, and streamlining game play.

Game Round
As the active player, place an Action marker on the common action selection board and resolve the associated action. Each opponent may, in turn order, spend a Reaction marker to follow, resolving a limited version of the same action, or pass.

Action Descriptions
Research
Acquire new technologies to improve the combat prowess and defensive abilities of your space ships or to enhance the effects of other actions. While the full technology tree is always available, offering full freedom to choose which technologies to research and in which order, previously acquired technologies allow related technologies to be researched at reduced cost.

Build Ships
Expand your fleet of Transport Ships, Light Fighters, Heavy Fighters, and War Cruisers, each represented by detailed unique miniatures. You will also have the option of building a Capital Ship, representing the pinnacle of your military achievements.

Buy Upgrades
Equip your ships with powerful cannons and shields, install faster drives, or add potent structures to planets under your control.

Mine/Trade
Uncover precious resources on planets in your empire or grow your influence on the trade market, thereby enhancing your economic options.

Harvest
Exploit planets for resources without which your economy will suffer and fall into ruin.

Conquest
Spend empire points to move your fleet, engage in combat in space or on the ground, explore new sectors, or annihilate neighboring planets with devastating nuclear missiles. Each type of cannon and missile is represented by a unique die.

Politics
Trigger political decisions, fueling intrigue between the factions. Claim goal cards and resupply with combat cards.

Refresh
Take back all of your Action markers, activate Home World abilities, repair ship damage, and claim goal cards.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
All Moles are trying to get the golden shovel to become Mega Mole of the Year. To defy all dangers, they first try to find their way into the vegetable garden of gardener Teitze.

It starts in the mole building, where all players place their mole. The tunnel has eleven event fields whose meaning should read aloud.

At the beginning the player rolls the dice and tries to roll a 4. On the cube it is the highest number, in addition there is a rock and a pic. So who dices the 4 may dig and is then right again at the turn.

If you roll a boulder, it means that there is a rockfall. Then you take a boulder and put it right in front of your field. You only pass the rock by rolling a pic. Even if the next moles arrive and might even pass by with their litter, they have to wait in front of the boulder.

So if one of the moles manages to roll a pimple, the rock is knocked out and the player is allowed to roll the dice again.

The event fields have different meanings. They can be to the advantage, but also to the detriment. Most of the events are negative and slow the mole down a bit. The events are really very sweet written and lovingly illustrated.

The winner is the first to reach the finish with the exact number of points.

—user summary

On your turn in the card game Plundering Pirates, you draw cards, then play cards to steal from other players, fight other players, or cause havoc with other players in an effort to obtain more cards that you can trade-in for coins. Once you've acquired enough coins, you can pay to reveal the "B.O.O.T.Y." — a plundering pirate's ultimate treasure!

Whoever pays for all of their "B.O.O.T.Y" cards first wins!

Hexiom is a 2 to 6 player abstract war game that can be played in single or 3 rounds.

Hexiom has no element of luck. Each player's turn consists of:

 Introduce a new hex tile at various heights with a player's unit on it.
 Reinforce an existing hex tile with multiple units.
 Transfer units between connected hex tiles.
 Attack other player's tiles using simple one-to-one elimination. The height of the hex adds bonus to the defender.




Winning the game - be the first to complete a row, or a ring, of 6 hex tiles controlled by the player.

Variable player perks - Hexiom features optional player perks layered on top of existing gameplay. Each player may choose one of 18 additional play rules to alter or extend the experience of the game.

—description from the designer

It's raining outside. The windows are misty but covered in drawings — drawings you made!

In Misty, players receive cards representing different designs and keep one for their window. They then give the other cards to their neighbor. After nine turns, each player has a magnificent window filled with drawings that will come to life in front of them: the balloons float up, the vehicles roll out, and the parachutes come down. Only some of the drawings can earn you points, though. The most beautiful and valuable drawing is the flower, but watch out for the monster who keeps on trying to erase it.

Misty is a tactical drafting game in which to win one must anticipate other players' moves and watch their windows.

During prohibition, it is better not to get caught handling illegal alcohol. Try to get rid of as many banned bottles as possible. When you are sure you have the least amount of alcohol, try your luck and shout “Omerta!”. Suspicious types and criminals can do you a favor but you can end up with more points than are needed to win.
2425Draw a card, choose one of five topics, roll the dice and find matching words for the dice. But be careful: you only have 30 seconds!

Pin sticks in the wooden board and be the first to align five sticks to win. Sticks come in four different heights. Taller sticks can replace shorter ones. Think ahead and constantly keep an eye on what’s changing on the board. Very few sticks stay pinned there forever. Play smart to force other players to bail you out.

A new title in our best-selling pocket collection. Kawaii is a dynamic card game where your goal is to get the most valuable pile before other players do so. In order to succeed you need to constantly observe other players’ actions, use your memory and act fast, with no hesitation.

The kittens need to go to the vet and they need to leave in 10 minutes, but where are they? They're misbehaving and being naughty! The owner needs to round up the kittens and get them to the vet. Mama Cat wants to protect the kittens and put them in her cardboard box. The kittens want to avoid both of them so they can play! The winner is the player who has control of the most kittens at the end of the game.

At the game start there are 9 kittens in the house as well as mama cat and the owner. The owner and mama cat will try each turn to capture one of the kittens and put them in the cat carrier or the cardboard box. The kittens of course, will try to hide or thwart the attempts of the other two. At the game end, whoever controls the most kittens wins. Mama cat controls kittens in the box, the owner controls kittens in the crate and the kitten player controls the kittens that still roam the house.

name.value: Talisman: Das Kartenspiel – Clash of Heroes

item.description:
Six adventurers, one goal — to go down in history as the greatest hero of all time. You can achieve fame through adventure, treasure, or direct confrontation, but the trick is to not lose it again. Magic talismans can make the way to fame easier, but these powerful artifacts are quickly lost again, then heroes who were on everyone's lips are soon forgotten...

Each turn in Talisman: Das Kartenspiel – Clash of Heroes, players can perform two actions to move across the modular board, open treasure chests, buy power cards, or attack teammates. Fighting in particular can increase your reputation in no time because for every life point the opponent loses, the attacker receives a fame point. Should a hero lose the last of their life, however, their attacker loses half of their previous glory points as well, which should ensure that the successful adventurer makes an attractive target. Whoever collects twelve glory points first wins.

Talisman: Das Kartenspiel – Clash of Heroes is a new, card-driven game for experience players in the Talisman universe.

The party game BAM! challenges players to fill in the blank on a card text in order to impress the "BAM!-Master" as well as the other players. If, for example, the question is "Germany is looking for BAM!?", you try to find an answer card in your hand that fits the situation best – or worst, as the case may be...

BAM!: Ultraschmutzig contains the best elements of the original BAM! as well as the standalone sequels BAM!: Extrahart and BAM! Ihr habt es so gewollt! with more than seven hundred cards that will allow players to fill those BAM!s in all kinds of ways

link.value: BAM! Ihr habt es so gewollt!

item.description:
Roll and move game of 105 circular spaces, with bonuses and penalties along the way. The game spaces form the edge of the board, around a map of Australia showing Flinders' voyages of 1801-02 and 1802-03. 
"An easy to play, educational game for young children based on the historical facts of Matthew Flinders' circumnavigation of Australia in his ship H.M.S. Investigator"

Roll-and-move game around a square track around the board edges, then around an outline map of Australia in the middle of the board. Certain squares allow a player to pick a card of a particular colour. Other squares are 'wild' and the player can collect any unclaimed card. Once all cards are claimed, players score points based on the size of their sets of cards of each colour. Cards feature Australian animals and places with a brief explanatory text.

Nut Punch! is a fast-paced card game aimed at drunken and juvenile delinquents at heart. With its easy to learn gameplay, even the most inebriated person can join in on the fun!

A mix between trick taking and the card game War, Nut Punch! is geared towards quick rounds so no one is out of the game longer than it takes to make a fresh round of drinks.

Developed by a former Marine with fellow Marines in mind, Nut Punch! is the perfect game to accommodate bored Marines/Corpsmen/Sailors/Soldiers/Airmen/Coasties/etc. out on deployment; whether it’s on the Ship, or in the field!

—description from the designer

Kill Your Friends is a card game that combines shedding, matching and knock-out style game play with a dark, brutal and twisted satire on modern life. (Think UNO crossed with Survivor with South Park style humour)

Win by being the last player left in the game or be the first player to have either no cards left or only cards of their colour left

The gameplay is fast paced, ruthless, unpredictable and fun, which creates an addictive game with a high replay value, with players desperate to seek revenge and redemption
 The illustrations provide a crude, shocking and provoking social commentary, covering topics such as depression, police brutality, addiction, bullying, health trends, and technology obsession

The content of the game is adults only and isn't for everyone, so if you are easily offended I would check out Splatatat! instead. Splatatat! is a family version of Kill Your Friends, which has the exact same game mechanics as Kill Your Friends but none of the violent and graphic content

—description from the publisher

Splatatat! is a card game that combines shedding, matching and knock-out style game play(Think UNO crossed with Survivor)

Each player chooses a colour to play as and each turn they have the option to splat another player, save themselves or use a slammy or ‘S’ card.

Win by being the last player left in the game or be the first player to have either no cards left or only cards of their colour left

Splatatat! is fast paced, ruthless, unpredictable and fun, which creates an addictive game with a high replay value, with players desperate to seek redemption.

Due to the unpredictable nature of the game, age or skill doesn’t have a bearing on the result (although some strategies can used, it doesn't guarantee a victory) which makes it a great to game to play with the whole family from old to young.

—description from the designer

Use different fish nets to gather as many fish as possible in Gone Fishing, then choose which fish you want to sell in the fish market to earn points. You must have delicate skills to catch more fish without chasing them out of your net!

You need to pick and choose the right fish as the value of each fish changes during the game. Players must choose wisely to raise the value of the fish they caught and catch the fish they need.

Fresh fish for bonus points! At the end of the game, each player throws their fish on the table. If the fish lands upward, the player receives a bonus point because fresh fish always taste better!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Don't worry about your artistic skills in Dekalko! You don't have to draw at all as now you can simply trace!

The game includes two hundred unique images in various themes (animals, sports, etc.) that players can draw! Trace your picture as quickly as you can, then show your drawing to the others to guess the picture. You can skip the details if you want to finish quickly! Once the original picture is hidden, however, your drawing may look unrecognizable compared to the original image...

In Little Dragons, you flip the face-down dragon eggs and look to find dragons that match. If you find eggs of the same kind, you can get more eggs at once, but you don't get any points at all if you find an empty egg. Collect the majority of each numbered egg to earn bonus points! Gather as many points as possible to win the game.

Unlike ordinary memory games, you need to have a good strategy and make the right choices to win in Little Dragons. It's not always the best strategy to remember where all the eggs are, but to remember and choose which eggs you want to collect to gain bonus points or to interfere with other players' strategy.

item.description:
An ultralight durable folding puzzle that fits in your wallet. Play it on your own or with family and friends.

The accompanying app provides endless folding challenges. Test your wits or race your friends to match the colours!

—description from the publisher

KALKÜL (Calculus) features a 5x5 wooden playing area, and each player has their own set of tokens numbered 1-4, which are placed in separate bags. Each area in the game board can hold up to four tokens, and players take turns drawing one of their tokens from their bag and placing it in one of the available locations.

The game ends once all the spaces are filled. If a player's tokens in a space have a larger sum than the opponent's, then that player has won that space. Win a majority of spaces on the game board to win the game.

KALKÜL includes two play variants:


 Leave all of the player tokens visible on the table, with players placing whichever token of theirs that they want on the game board.
 Place all of the tokens in the same bag. Whether you draw your token or your opponent's, place that on the game board.

The men who built the railways arrived with sound boots and got their shovels on credit; they were issued tickets, in payment for their work, which could be spent at the Tommy Shop or (more likely) on beer! As a ganger, or foreman, you are responsible for your own team of navvies as they travel through Mid and North Wales: digging the track beds, laying the rails, and occasionally helping a passenger or two along their way. Foothills lets you participate in grand-scale railway construction while paying attention to the small details; manage your navvies' work carefully, and you should be able to let them go to the pub at the end of the day.

Foothills is a tactical and intriguing one- or two-player card game from new designer Ben Bateson and the designer of Snowdonia, Tony Boydell. Using your five action cards cleverly, collect resources, remove rubble, build track and stations, and use the action spaces you unlock, all the while collecting more victory points than your opponent. In the end, the player with the most victory points wins!

—description from the designer

It's a beautiful day on the island, and the turtles want to frolic on the warm beach rather than in the cold water, but the island doesn't have room for everyone.

In Turtle Mania, players want to help create a space on the island for the turtles as they arrive, but to do this, they need to push other turtles aside. On a turn, you have to push a turtle from a pier onto the beach, ideally without any other turtles falling into the water because if they do, you have to keep them as punishment, tending to their needs.

If you knock a yellow turtle into the water, you must take a turn again immediately. If you have collected three turtles of the same color or seven turtles total, then the game ends and you are out. Whoever has collected the fewest turtles aside from you wins.

History and goal

In the spring of 2016, 6 committed citizens met to do "something" on the subject of Mobility: Professor Cathy Macharis of the VUI, Karin De Schepper of Insland Navigation & CleanAirBXL, Steven Vanden brande of Durabrik, Guibert Boone of Fockedey, Miguel Vertriest of Duurzame Mobiliteit (sustainable mobility) and Koen De Maesschalck of Colruyt Group.

Under the supervision of Sandra Schruijer, professor Organisation science at the University of Utrecht, they concluded that the game could maybe help us relieve our mobility tangle. Inspired by the work of Laurent Bontoux of JRC (European Commission) they made a mobility game intended to connect people, show empathy for each other's role and let new ideas surface. After an elaborate testing round, the game was launched on 21 June 2017 at the Mobility Congress

In this game players will take turns playing action cards to build arguments for their goals. Other players can vote on what arguments they like.
You get points by having other people vote for your arguments.

—user summary

item.description:
Mortals: Descent of the Gods is a cooperative battle-arena board game set in a museum in modern times. You and your friends play as Greek, Norse, and Egyptian gods that have been made Mortal by Death himself. Now, with the world coming to an end, you and your fellow once-gods are being called out of ambiguity to fight Death and unlock his secrets within the walls of this museum. Can you halt the engine of Earth's destruction?

—description from the publisher

name.value: Mortal Gods: Skirmish Games In Ancient Greece

item.description:
Greece has proven her might and the forces of the vast Persian Empire have been repulsed. Each City-State believes it played a key part in the victory and this new-found pride has brought about rivalry, greed and conflict.

Generals and statesmen vie for power and wealth in the chaos, risking exile or execution while the boldest and ambitious gather to them their Hoplites; these tough warriors, armour clad and trained in war, stand loyal to their archon’s city or ideals. The price of failure being exile or death.

In this age of strife and conflict, bold men may seize greatness and become as Mortal Gods!

Mortal Gods is a skirmish tabletop game played with roughly 15-25 models on each side. Players select their force before each game based around a single heroic leader, or ‘Lochagos’, along with a number of loyal companions.

Battles are swift and bloody as players alternate acting with one warrior or a group of warriors – moving and fighting to achieve the scenario objectives, whether that be cutting down the enemy, defending an outpost or finding and protecting an important character.

As you play through the game, your hero will acquire new skills, and perhaps even catch the eye of the gods to gain victory – such choices are what create Mortal Gods.

This is your time, to carve your name, in the history of Ancient Greece!

—description from the publisher

link.value: Mortal Gods: Skirmish Games In Ancient Greece – Athenian Lochos
Mortal Gods: Skirmish Games In Ancient Greece – Spartan Lochos

item.description:
Timmy's things are scattered all over the place, but he should be packing for the upcoming holiday! For some reason, you're concerned that his parents not notice that Timmy prefers to play instead of pack, so you've decided to help him get all his stuff ready so that the family can go on vacation as planned.

In Timmy macht Urlaub (Timmy's Vacation), you roll the dice, then try to attach an item of the rolled color to Timmy without dropping anything. If the players manage to set up Timmy with all the items without any of them falling, they win together and Timmy can set off on vacation.

Mount Rushmore is a game of quick wit and keen eye. Visit Mount Rushmore, an iconic American monument, and test your perception and speed!

Each turn, a Search card will be revealed. All players will look for a Monument card that matches the face-up Search card. The player who first discovered the correct Monument card wins the current round and gets to keep the Search card. Each Search card is worth 1 point. Be the first to score 3 points to win!

Mount Rushmore can be played at different difficulty levels. For a lighter, more family-friendly game we recommend the Basic Game setup. For a more challenging experience you may try the Advanced Game instead. For a full mind-bending experience of Mount Rushmore you may set up an Expert Game.

—description from the publisher

Battle Axe is a simple to play tabletop system for skirmish level battles. Using cards instead of dice, you will find the game to be less luck based and much more tactical in nature.

Taking the best that CCG and Table Top gaming have to offer, and combining them, you end up with a system that offers endless option and expansion. The rules and cards provide here will be enough to get you started, and new characters and rule expansions are on the way so you can continue to increase both the size and composition of your War Bands.

This base set offers you the following...


 Full color, detailed rule with plenty of examples and diagram to highlight important concepts.
 Full Color Combat Charts
 60 card Fate deck, in full color
 The Elven and Goblin Starting War Bands, which included the faction deck for both races, and three character decks for both, which covers the Elven Warrior, the Elven Archer and the Elven Blade Dancer. On the Goblin side we have the Goblin Thug, the Goblin Warrior and the Goblin Archer. These will give you a good start on the game and additional characters and factions can be purchased as they are released


—description from the publisher

name.value: Wau Wau Muh und was machst du?

item.description:
A new day starts on the farm, with animals and humans both rising to start the day and ready to eat! Can you help the farmers feed their animals?

In Wau Wau Muh und was machst du?, players get task cards to show what food they need to find, and once they do find it under the hidden tiles, then they feed the corresponding animal by pushing the food into its mouth and making the appropriate sound. If you complete most of the tasks by the time all the tokens have been distributed, you win.
